OMS stands for Order Management System, which is a software platform used in eCommerce to manage and track orders from the time they are placed to the time they are delivered to the customer. An OMS is designed to streamline the order fulfillment process and ensure that orders are processed and shipped quickly and accurately.

Some of the key features of an OMS include:

Order processing: An OMS can automate the process of receiving and processing orders from multiple channels, including online marketplaces, websites, and brick-and-mortar stores.

Inventory management: An OMS can help manage inventory levels and provide real-time visibility into stock levels across multiple sales channels.

Shipping and tracking: An OMS can automate the shipping process and provide tracking information for each order, which can improve customer satisfaction.

Returns management: An OMS can streamline the process of processing returns and exchanges, including issuing refunds and restocking returned products.

Reporting and analytics: An OMS can provide detailed reports and analytics on order and inventory data, which can help eCommerce businesses make informed decisions about inventory levels, sales channels, and more.

Overall, an OMS is an essential tool for eCommerce businesses that want to streamline their order management process, improve efficiency, and provide a better customer experience. in Tech topic.

WMS stands for Warehouse Management System, which is a software platform used in eCommerce to manage and track inventory and warehouse operations. A WMS is designed to help eCommerce businesses optimize their warehouse operations, improve inventory accuracy, and increase productivity.

Some of the key features of a WMS include:

Inventory management: A WMS can track inventory levels in real-time, including receiving, put-away, picking, and shipping of products.

Order fulfillment: A WMS can manage and prioritize the order picking process to ensure that orders are fulfilled accurately and on time.

Barcode scanning and labeling: A WMS can use barcode scanning and labeling to ensure accurate inventory counts and reduce errors in the picking and shipping processes.

Automation: A WMS can automate many warehouse processes, including inventory tracking, order picking, and shipping, which can improve efficiency and reduce labor costs.

Reporting and analytics: A WMS can provide detailed reports and analytics on warehouse operations, which can help eCommerce businesses make informed decisions about inventory levels, order fulfillment, and more.

Overall, a WMS is an essential tool for eCommerce businesses that want to optimize their warehouse operations, improve accuracy, and increase productivity. By using a WMS, eCommerce businesses can manage their inventory and warehouse operations more efficiently, reduce errors, and provide a better customer experience. in Tech topic.

Wholesale is divided into 2 parts:

-Private Label: which are the brands we manufacture ourselves (i.e Atmos&Here)

-Branded: Brands that we own (ships from our warehouse, but we don’t own (i.e La Coste.. )

Both are owned by the iconic and ships from our warehouse in Company Terms topic.

Branded is further broken into 2 parts - Consignment and Wholesale - Wholesale is technically when we buy the stock completely for the cost price and own it completely, so any profit or loss we make on it is ours.  Consignment is when we get the stock with promise of paying once we sell them, so if the stock doesn't sell through, we are entitled to return it back to the supplier and so won't be making a loss on stuff not sold. in Company Terms topic.
Items not owned by us, and don’t ship from our warehouse, but we sell them on the website. in Company Terms topic.

Total Net Merchandise Value (Total NMV) is defined as the value of goods (within both retail and marketplace segment) sold after actual and provisioned returns and rejections. Net of VAT. in GFG Metrics topic.
Retail Net Merchandise Value (Retail NMV) is defined as the value of goods sold after actual and provisioned returns and rejections. Net of VAT. in GFG Metrics topic.
Marketplace Net Merchandise Value (Marketplace NMV) is defined as the value of goods sold after actual and provisioned returns and rejections. Net of VAT. in GFG Metrics topic.

Total original price value of retail goods sold after actual and provisioned cancellations relating to the period and before adjustments for discounts/coupons/markdowns and actual and provisioned rejections/returns. Net of VAT. (Total, retail, marketplace) in GFG Metrics topic.

Market Size Definition:
All data to be net of tax and based on price paid, i.e. post discounts/ coupons. Offline + online retail market of apparel, footwear, beauty & personal care as well as beauty accessories Excluding black-market sales (i.e. untaxed, generated within informal retailing) and duty free sales (travel retail) Antique and/ or vintage clothing and footwear is also excluded Beauty & Personal care is the aggregation of baby and child-specific products, bath & shower, deodorants, hair care, colour cosmetics, men's grooming, oral hygiene, fragrances, skin care, depilatories, sun care and sets/kits. This is the aggregation of premium colour cosmetics, fragrances, deodorants, skin care, sun care, baby and child-specific products, bath and shower and hair care If you are using a different definition compared to the above, please do reach out pro-actively to discuss and make it transparent. Market Size to be shown in EUR'm.

Market Share (%) Definition:

Market share (%) = Total NMV (G1) / Market Size
Important to ensure that same underlying exchange rates are used for Total NMV (G1) and Market Size in GFG Metrics topic.

Total number of customers who made at least one net purchase in the last twelve months at the end of the period. in GFG Metrics topic.
